qas.question: What did European mysticism concentrate on that English mysticism didn't?

answers.text: ecstatic experiences of union with the divine

qas.question: English mysticism was composed of how many elements?
What is one element of English Dominican mysticism?

answers.text: it emulated the moral essence of Christ's life

qas.question: What was the focus of English Dominican mysticism?

plausible_answers.text: ecstatic experiences of union with the divine

qas.question: What did European mysticism and English mysticism both concentrate on?

plausible_answers.text: on a crucial dynamic in one's personal relationship with God

qas.question: What was not a focus for English Dominican mysticism?
Which mysticism was composed of 5 elements?

plausible_answers.text: the means for reformation of humanity's nature

qas.question: What was not an image of divinity?

plausible_answers.text: the supreme aspiration of this mysticism

qas.question: What was not ethical or an actual union of God?

context: English Dominican mysticism in the late medieval period differed from European strands of it in that, whereas European Dominican mysticism tended to concentrate on <a0_0><b4_0>ecstatic experiences of union with the divine<b4_0/><a0_0/>, <b6_0>English Dominican<b6_0/> mysticism's ultimate focus was <b5_0>on a crucial dynamic in <a3_0>one's personal relationship with God<b5_0/><a3_0/>. This was an essential moral imitation of the Savior as an ideal for religious change, and as <b7_0>the means for reformation of humanity's nature<b7_0/> as an image of divinity. This type of mysticism carried with it <a1_0>four<a1_0/> elements. First, spiritually <a2_0>it emulated the moral essence of Christ's life<a2_0/>. Second, there was a connection linking moral emulation of Christ's life and humanity's disposition as images of the divine. Third, English Dominican mysticism focused on an embodied spirituality with a structured love of fellow men at its center. Finally, <b8_0>the supreme aspiration of this mysticism<b8_0/> was either an ethical or an actual union with God.
